news_item.title: Galen presented at ICWSM on community values on Reddit
news_item.description: At ICWSM 2022 in Atlanta, Galen presented his paper surveying users and analyzing over two thousand subreddits for their values. The paper title is: "What Makes Online Communities ‘Better’? Measuring Values, Consensus, and Conflict across Thousands of Subreddits".

news_item.title: Amy received a Google Research Scholar Award on personalized content moderation
news_item.description: Amy received a Google Research Scholar Award which will provide funding for the lab's research on "Designing End User Tools for Personalized Content Moderation".

news_item.title: Anson, Emelia, Felicia, and Renee presented their research at the Undergrad Research Symposium
news_item.description: Felicia gave a presentation on her analysis of governance files on Github repositories, while Anson, Emelia, and Renee presented a poster about their project to add citations to videos on YouTube.

news_item.title: SFL at CHI 2022!
news_item.description: Our lab went to an in-person conference for the first time! Amy gave a keynote in the "Designing for Mis/Disinformation" workshop on user and community approaches to countering misinformation, Kevin presented a workshop paper at the InContext workshop on designer, developer, and data science collaboration, Shagun presented a paper coauthored with Jim on designing word filter tools for creator-led comment moderation, and Ruotong attended as a student volunteer!

news_item.title: Congrats to Simona for being named to the Husky 100
news_item.description: Undergrad RA Simona Liao was named to the Husky 100, which recognizes 100 UW undergraduate and graduate students who are making the most of their time at the UW!

news_item.title: We received a gift from the C2PA to conduct research on media provenance indicators
news_item.description: The C2PA (Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity) is a coalition of industry and non-profit organizations coming together to develop technical standards for media provenance. We are collaborating with the C2PA on UX research to understand how media provenance indicators on social media impact how people interact with and trust media.

news_item.title: We received a gift from Meta to build tools for triaging misinformation
news_item.description: SFL received a grant from Meta on a project to build tools for understanding and triaging the different degrees of misinformation harms.

news_item.title: SFL at CSCW!
news_item.description: Lots of SFL activity at CSCW this year! Jim gave a presentation on his work on Goldilocks.  Amy and Ruotong co-organized a workshop on "Subtle CSCW Traits".  Peipei won an honorable mention and D&I award for her work at UMSI on disproportional content removals. Shagun, an alumi of our lab, won two honorable mention awards for his work on platform migration and from GATech on deplatforming. Amy had a paper on modular politics as well as one from MIT on interventions against misinformation sharing.

news_item.title: We received a gift from AI2 to explore collaborative literature review
news_item.description: In collaboration with the Semantic Scholar research team at the Allen Institute for AI (AI2), we will be working on collaborative tools to support teams with discovering academic literature.

news_item.title: We received a grant from the UW CIP on a tool for correcting misinformation
news_item.description: In collaboration with Franzi Roesner at UW CSE, we will be kicking off work on a tool for correcting misinformation on Twitter, thanks to a grant from UW CIP.

news_item.title: We received an NSF grant on abuse prevention in end-to-end encrypted environments
news_item.description: In collaboration with Cornell Tech and Cornell, we will be working over the next several years on community-based moderation tools to combat abuse in end-to-end encrypted environments, such as Signal, WhatsApp, etc., where little platform oversight and moderation is possible.

news_item.title: We received two NSF Convergence Accelerator grants on combating online misinformation
news_item.description: One project will be on using digital juries to develop more legitimate processes for determining judgements on difficult misinformation content moderation cases, led by UMSI. A second project will build tools to support laypeople in having conversations and building trust in order to correct misinformation in their local networks.

news_item.title: Welcome Alice, Jesse, and Peipei to SFL
news_item.description: Alice, Jesse, and Peipei are joining for the summer to help out on research projects! Alice joins us on a CRA DREU summer internship on a project studying personal content moderation tools. Jesse will be working part-time on the digital juries project. And Peipei will be working part-time on studying misinformation harms.

news_item.title: Skyler wins the Allen School Outstanding Senior Award
news_item.description: Skyler is one of three undergraduates to receive the Outstanding Senior Award from the Allen School for his exceptional academic performance, significant contribution to the advancement of knowledge, and demonstrated leadership potential and good citizenship. Congrats Skyler!

news_item.title: Emelia and Renee present their work at an ICWSM workshop on misinformation
news_item.description: Emelia and Renee presented their workshop paper on Youtube credibility signals in collaboration with Prerna Juneja and Prof. Tanu Mitra at the ICWSM workshop on "Information Credibility & Alternative Realities in Troubled Democracies". In addition to that paper, Amy had another paper at the workshop with collaborators from Credibility Coalition on UX design guidelines and evaluation frameworks for credibility tools.

news_item.title: Shagun will be giving a talk on 'Designing Transparent & Effective Content Moderation' at the UW DUB seminar this week
news_item.description: Talk Abstract: Social media sites like Facebook, Twitter and Reddit make millions of decisions everyday about which posts can stay online and which posts are removed. How these moderation decisions are made has important consequences for many of the key problems that the Internet faces today - fake news, online harassment, online radicalization, and censorship. My research builds a foundation for designing transparent and effective content moderation systems. I compliment data science methods with qualitative methods to (1) incorporate fairness and transparency in content removals and (2) examine the effectiveness of a range of moderation strategies in combating online hate groups. My findings show that (1) offering explanations for post removals improves both user attitudes and user behaviors and (2) implementing design frictions that impede access to controversial communities makes it more difficult for hate groups to recruit new members. In this talk, I will discuss how I conducted this research and articulate the lessons learned from this work for the benefit of site managers, moderators, and designers of moderation systems.

news_item.title: Emelia will be presenting her work at UW's Undergraduate Research Symposium
news_item.description: Emelia's work on YouTube credibility signals and citations has been accepted to the Undergraduate Research Symposium. She will be giving a ten minute presentation on her work during session 3 of the symposium.

news_item.title: We received a grant from Hacks/Hackers on a project with WEF to study online misinformation harms
news_item.description: Hacks/Hackers has funded our latest project to characterize harms in online misinformation in collaboration with Connie Moon Sehat, Senior Fellow at the World Economic Forum and Director of the NewsQ Initiative, and Tarunima Prabhakar of Tattle. Skyler and Ryan in our lab will be helping out on this project.

news_item.title: Welcome Renee, Anson, Adithi, Ryan, and Detlef to SFL
news_item.description: After a very successful ACM Research Night presentation by lab members last quarter, 5 undergraduate students have officially joined our lab! Renee and Ryan will be working on topics related to misinformation, Anson will be focusing on civic tech, Adithi will be analyzing cross-cultural studies in HCI, and Detlef will be working on tools to combat online harassment.

news_item.title: Ge and Jiajia have accepted PhD positions at UMSI and CMU HCII
news_item.description: Ge will be pursuing a PhD at UMSI in the fall, while Jiajia will be starting at CMU HCII for her PhD. Congrats Ge and Jiajia!!

news_item.title: Jim's recent work on improving crowdsourced scalar annotations to appear in CSCW '21
news_item.description: Jim's recent work "Goldilocks: Consistent Crowdsourced Scalar Annotations with Relative Uncertainty" to appear in CSCW.

news_item.title: Emelia presented at MozFest on her YouTube credibility project
news_item.description: Emelia joined WikiCred at MozFest to present her recent work on the WikiUX: Introducing Credibility Signals and Citations Signals and Citations to Youtube project.

news_item.title: Ruotong won a CHI Best Paper Honorable Mention
news_item.description: Ruotong won a Best Paper Honorable Mention recognition for the paper "Tabletop games in the Age of Remote Collaboration: Design Opportunities for a Socially Connected Game Experience", where she is a co-author.

news_item.title: Amy joins the UW Center for an Informed Public as a faculty member
news_item.description: Amy is joining the UW CIP for a two-year term. The CIP's mission is to resist strategic misinformation, promote an informed society, and strengthen democratic discourse.

news_item.title: Shagun will be a panelist for the UChicago event: "The Great Deplatforming: Implications of Big Tech Censorship"
news_item.description: This is a moderated panel of experts in law, technology, and policy discussing the implications of the historic deplatforming of a US president, as well recent moves by tech companies to mitigate hate speech online.

news_item.title: Amy appeared on the podcast "Reimagining the Internet"
news_item.description: Amy is interviewed by Ethan Zuckerman on his podcast hosted at the Institute for Digital Public Infrastructure at UMass Amherst. The podcast series is about what's wrong with social media and how to fix it.

news_item.title: Skyler Hallinan joins as undergrad RA
news_item.description: Skyler is joining the lab as an undergrad RA to work on taxonomizing and classifying misinformation harms. Skyler recently won an undergraduate award for his prior research on bioengineering!

news_item.title: We won a grant from UW iSchool for designing systems to signal credibility.
news_item.description: We won a grant from the UW iSchool's Strategic Research Fund along with our collaborator in the iSchool, Prof. Tanu Mitra. This grant  will go towards Emelia May Hughes's research on applying credibility signals in Youtube.

news_item.title: The Social Futures Lab is started, with Shagun joining as a postdoc and Jim and Ruotong joining as grad students.
news_item.description: Shagun joins the lab as a postdoc, working on online harassment tools. Jim (co-advised by Dan Weld) and Ruotong (co-advised by Katharina Reinecke) join as graduate students. In addition, Ge and Wenjia join as visiting researchers, and Emelia joins as an undergraduate student. Ricky continues his summer work on PolicyKit.

news_item.title: Amy named a Belfer Fellow by the Anti-Defamation League to work on tools to fight harassment.
news_item.description: The Belfer Fellowship program advances ADL’s work by promoting cyberhate awareness and digital citizenship, as well as implementing these projects for the wider social good. Zhang’s project is to build an interactive tool for people facing harassment that allows them to iteratively develop their own personal machine learning model that is customized to detect the harassment they wish to intercept, all without the need for programming skills.

news_item.title: Amy's PhD thesis wins the MIT EECS George Sprowls Award for best PhD thesis in computer science.
news_item.description: Amy's thesis is titled "Systems for Collective Human Curation of Online Discussion" and was supervised by David Karger.

news_item.title: We won a micro-grant from WikiCred to work on the UX of credibility on Wikipedia.
news_item.description: WikiCred is a partnership between MisinfoCon, The Credibility Coalition, and the Wikimedian communities that started with WikiConference North America 2019. Funders include Craig Newmark’s Philanthropies, Microsoft and Facebook. The project examines how end-users respond to different types of credibility signals such as the page structure, tone of writing, and placement of citations within Wikipedia articles, as well as Wikipedia content that exists elsewhere on the web, like information cards on the search and social platforms.

news_item.title: Amy accepts a position at the Allen School starting in fall 2020.
news_item.description: She will be conducting research at UW CSE on social computing and HCI.
